Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Extending anchored phylogenomics into plants with a case study of beaksedge (tribe Rhynchosporeae; Cyperaceae) diversification in the New World
Award.AbstractNarration:
The beaksedges (ca. 375 spp. in tribe Rhynchosporeae; Cyperaceae) are ideal for understanding patterns of diversity and diversification in the three American centers of subtropical/tropical grasslands and savanna because they are one of the most diverse groups in each area. For example, Rhynchospora has the greatest number of taxa (49) endemic to the SE North American Coastal Plain of any plant genus. This study will use 'anchored phylogenomics' (identifying and sequencing 100s or 1000s of highly conserved anchor regions flanked by more variable regions scattered throughout the genome) to produce a robust phylogeny for ca. 100 beaksedge species that will be used to the timing of diversification of the group and the evolution of fruit morphology, habitat specificity, and C3/C4 photosynthesis.

The project will generate a 'toolkit' for anchored phylogenomics in the monocots, a group of 65,000 species that provides the great majority of the human diet (e.g., rice, maize, and wheat). Better knowledge of the relationships among these crop plants and their wild relatives is useful in crop improvement. The project will also enable more precise identifications of beaksedge species, which are often only identified to genus in ecological and conservation studies because of difficulties in identification. This is especially significant because 81 beaksedge species are recognized as wetland indicators in the United States and under-representation of the tribe's diversity reduces the accuracy of conservation assessments and makes the study of some ecological interactions impossible. The project will also train a graduate student in phylogenomics, which is emerging as an increasingly important skill set in systematics, biogeography, ecology, and evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant funded the training of a graduate student in a cutting-edge genomics pipeline and analysis method for inferring the Tree of Life (genome-scale data collection for this purpose is often referred to as "phylogenomics"). In the course of the student's work, he and collaborators introduced a new tool for phylogenomics that appears to work across the 300,000 flowering plant species. This tool targets 500 spots (called "loci") in the nuclear DNA of flowering plants for "enrichment" prior to high-throughput genomic sequencing.  This enrichment leads to most of the data generated being from those 500 loci, which were chosen to minimize inference problems, such as those introduced by gene duplications.  The student and collaborators demonstrated the success of the tool using data from >100 angiosperms, representing much of the evolutionary breadth of that group. This is potentially transformative for the field of plant phylogenomics, since it can lead to the same loci being targeted across many individual studies, leading to a grand combination of data.  The student and collaborators also demonstrated the success of the tool using the student's focal group of angiosperms, the beaksedges.  The beaksedges (called tribe Rhynchosporeae) are distinctive in the southeastern coastal plain of North America for having the greatest number of species wholly restricted to that geographic feature.  The student's research showed that all but a small number of the species in the coastal plain are from a single, rapid diversification that began about 10 million years ago.
